column4: Is it possible to see if a packages is installed by default with my distribution?
!clone
I'm not sure how that addresses my question
But does that show which ones I installed and which are default packages
I got the package name with dpkg -S like you said
If I installed it or if it was already installed with my distribution
i.e. if it would be available on a parallel distribution without any additional configuration
I'm interested to know whether it's a process that's generally available to Ubuntu users with their distributions or not
I would also be interested to see a list of packages I have installed over the year
Which would ultimately show me the same thing
dpkg -l
That also includes things I did not install
I guess there's no way to tell the difference between a package that admin(s) installed and those which were included already?
But, the easiest way to know for sure what's installed by default is to look in the .manifest file of the liveCD: http://releases.ubuntu.com/9.04/ubuntu-9.04-desktop-i386.manifest
There's no difference between those packages.
That is a shame
It's 0 bytes
preinstalled isn't any different than "I installed it".  That's how some of the installers operate (just taking packages and installing them).
dpkg.log is 0 bytes
Yeah they are
That does look a lot like the things I installed although it includes a lot of dependancies that I don't recognise
http://releases.ubuntu.com/9.04/ubuntu-9.04-desktop-i386.manifest lists everything a default install has.
(well, for 9.04 Ubuntu on i386)
